articles.title: OBSERVER: Designing sponge cities with Copernicus Land
articles.summary:
OBSERVER: Designing sponge cities with Copernicus Land 
sonia
Thu, 21/08/2025 - 10:34

Cities are racing to adapt to heavier cloudbursts, rising flood risk, and hotter summers. The sponge city approach treats streets, parks, and waterways as living infrastructure which slows, stores, and cleans rain where it falls, improving liveability and biodiversity while easing pressure on drainage systems. The Copernicus Land Monitoring Service (CLMS) provides the consistent, high-resolution information needed to plan and monitor these nature-based solutions, from mapping sealed surfaces to monitoring tree cover and surface water. In this Observer, we show how CLMS supports sponge city design, point to lessons from Copenhagen and Wuhan, and highlight the datasets planners can use to measure and improve urban sponginess.
 
 
In July 2011, the city of Copenhagen, Denmark experienced a flooding event which would change it forever. Above the city, a warm air mass coming from the south collided with the cooler air over southern Scandinavia. As warm, wet air rose quickly, it cooled and condensed, forming towering cumulonimbus clouds which opened like floodgates and dropped a staggering 135 mm of rain on Copenhagen in less than 2 hours.
This event, known as a “cloudburst”, left a massive trail of destruction in its wake. The extensive flooding submerged basements, crippled transportation networks, and caused the sewers to back up into the streets. There were power outages across the city and emergency services were absolutely overwhelmed. Though fortunately there were no fatalities, it was a wakeup call for a city which was completely unprepared for such an event.
 
Investing in the future
The 2011 cloudburst became a catalyst for the city, providing the necessary justification for a €1.3 billion investment in flood preparedness. The first part of the plan is nearly complete. Copenhagen has built a series of seven enormous tunnels beneath the city designed to hold 10,000 cubic metres of water, equal to the volume of four Olympic swimming pools. These tunnels will be necessary to deal with future cloudburst and extreme rainfall events, but to address the more frequent but less severe storms, Copenhagen has taken a different approach, transforming streets, parks, and public spaces into dynamic elements of the stormwater management system. From sunken playgrounds which double as collection basins to tree-lined boulevards which channel water safely downhill, Copenhagen’s urban fabric is being reimagined to manage water where it falls.
This idea has come to be known as the sponge city approach, a model of climate-resilient urban design which integrates green and blue infrastructure into the urban fabric in a way which mimics natural hydrological processes like slowing runoff, absorbing excess rainwater, and filtering pollutants before they reach waterways. By weaving nature into the city, the sponge city approach not only reduces flood risk but also supports biodiversity, improves air quality, and enhances urban liveability.


(Left) An area of the Sydhavn neighbourhood in Copenhagen containing Karens Minde Park, as seen by the Copernicus Sentinel-2 Global Image Mosaic, showcasing one of the city's many sponge infrastructures. (Right) Photograph of the walkable canal during a dry period. Credit: European Union, Copernicus Land Monitoring Service.

 
So far, the city has transformed more than 20 green spaces into sponge parks. Take Karens Minde Park in the Sydhavn neighbourhood for example. This low-lying green space is capable of holding up to 15,000 cubic metres of stormwater, equivalent to about 1.5 of the city’s underground cloudburst tunnels. A 600-metre-long tiled channel winds through the park, guiding rainwater through a series of trickle meadows which help filter out sediment before it flows into a retention basin. Through a simple excavation project, Copenhagen was able to construct a walkable riverbed which becomes a major waterway during heavy rain, protecting the neighbourhood of Sydhavn from flooding while providing a vibrant public space the rest of the year.
 
Assessing sponginess
These individual examples of successful green infrastructure are important, but city planners and researchers also need tools to assess how well the urban landscape absorbs water overall. One method for measuring a city’s “sponginess” is based on Arup’s Three-Factor Model, which looks at three key aspects: green and blue space coverage, soil permeability, and runoff potential. 
The Copernicus Land Monitoring Service provides standardised, free and open, high-resolution datasets which can help evaluate each of these components. For example, the Urban Atlas (UA) product, which provides detailed land cover/land use maps for 788 Functional Urban Areas across Europe, can be used as a first step to map land cover types across a city, offering a snapshot of potential absorption zones. 
To get more specific, layers like the High Resolution Layer (HRL) Imperviousness can be added. This product is designed to identify artificially sealed surfaces and how sealing has changed over time, helping planners identify opportunities to "green the grey”.
Even finer detail comes from products such as the Tree Cover Density and HRL Small Woody Features, which provide information about tree cover density and the presence of small, linear, or patchy vegetation features such as hedgerows and tree lines, respectively. This helps urban planners distinguish, for example, between a mown lawn and a dense grove of trees, both of which show as green on a satellite image, but are very different in terms of how much water they can absorb.
By combining these datasets, cities can build a detailed map of their current hydrological situation, highlight areas which need improvement, and track progress as new sponge infrastructure is added.


Copenhagen, Denmark. Examples of the various CLMS datasets which can be used in the context of urban sponginess assessment. Going clockwise, Corine Land Cover (CLC), HRL Imperviousness, Tree Cover Density (TCD), and HRL Small Woody Features (SWF). Credit: European Union, Copernicus Land Monitoring Service.

 
Wuhan’s Sponge City Initiative
These days, the popularity of sponge cities has gone global. In the last decade, China has been particularly eager to adopt this model of urban design, with Wuhan standing out as one of China’s flagship sponge cities. Located within the Yangtze River basin, Wuhan is very vulnerable to extreme flash flooding events, which have increased in frequency and intensity over recent decades as a consequence of climate change. By improving natural water retention and absorption across the city, Wuhan has become a model of urban resilience with an improved ability to reduce flood risk and adapt to the mounting challenges of climate change. 
Wuhan began implementing sponge city principles in 2015, allocating over €3 billion to projects such as wetland restoration, permeable pavements, urban forests, and expanded blue-green corridors. These natural and engineered systems work synergistically to absorb and retain stormwater, reduce surface runoff, and filter pollutants, while also providing crucial co-benefits including biodiversity preservation and improved quality of life.
Economic analyses suggest that investments in sponge city infrastructure in Wuhan ended up being €600 million cheaper than grey infrastructure alternatives, while delivering additional social and ecological benefits. For instance, during the 2016 flood season, Wuhan’s sponge city features are estimated to have prevented approximately €150 million in direct flood damage by absorbing runoff and delaying peak flows in vulnerable neighbourhoods. Moreover, by reducing the load on drainage and wastewater treatment systems, these nature-based solutions contribute to long-term operational savings and decreased maintenance costs. Beyond direct economic benefits, sponge city investments generate wider environmental and social returns. Urban cooling effects from increased vegetation improve liveability and reduce heat-related health risks, while the improved air quality and expanded green space boost public health and property values. 


Wuhan, China with examples of global CLMS products (right panel) which can support in planning and monitoring of green and blue infrastructure around the world. Credit: European Union, Copernicus Land Monitoring Service/Larcomar via Pixabay.

 
CLMS global portfolio
Monitoring the success and progress of sponge city initiatives requires detailed, accurate, and timely data. Here, CLMS can offer invaluable support through high resolution (both spatial and temporal) data such as the Water Bodies and Land Cover Forest Monitoring (LCFM) product suites. Water Bodies products offer a near real-time overview of surface water extent across the world, capturing seasonal and longer-term variations on a monthly basis at 100m resolution in lakes, rivers, and wetlands. This product can help city planners track how natural water bodies respond to rainfall events, assess floodplain connectivity, and identify areas where water retention capacity can be improved. 
Complementing this, the global 10m resolution Tree Cover Density dataset offers detailed insights into the condition and changes of forested areas across the tropics, including in Wuhan. Forests play a fundamental role in urban hydrology by intercepting rainfall, promoting infiltration, and reducing surface runoff. Healthy forest cover acts as a natural sponge, slowing the flow of water and allowing it to percolate into the soil, thereby reducing flood peaks and improving water quality.
The 10m resolution global Land Cover layer can also play a crucial role in tracking various land cover classes, including the important Tree Cover class. While dense forests are rarely found within urban areas, the Tree Cover class is often present and highly relevant. The LCFM product monitors forest dynamics such as deforestation, afforestation, and degradation with high spatial and temporal resolution. This enables planners and environmental managers to assess whether sponge city initiatives, such as reforestation or urban greening projects, are effectively increasing tree cover and improving natural water retention. For example, newly planted urban forests or restored riparian buffers can be identified, and their impact on local hydrology evaluated over time. Conversely, areas experiencing forest loss or degradation can be flagged as potential vulnerabilities where flood risk may increase.
As climate change accelerates and extreme weather events become more frequent, cities around the world are rethinking how they manage water. Copenhagen and Wuhan, two cities on opposite sides of the globe, provide compelling examples of how sponge city principles can deliver long-term economic and ecological benefits. However, making cities more absorbent isn’t just about big infrastructure projects. It’s also about data. With detailed, high-resolution products from CLMS, planners and policymakers can target the right interventions and monitor the impacts of nature-based solutions over time. In this way, satellite data becomes an important ingredient in building greener, more resilient cities. Cities that don’t just survive the next storm but thrive in its aftermath.

articles.personality_title: How cities like Copenhagen and Wuhan use nature and data to fight floods
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Many cities face heavier storms, floods, and hotter summers. To handle this, some are turning to the "sponge city" idea. This means designing parks, streets, and waterways to soak up rainwater like a sponge, which helps reduce floods and makes cities nicer to live in.

**What happened** – After a huge flood in 2011, Copenhagen invested over €1 billion to prepare for future storms. The city built big tunnels underground to hold floodwater and changed parks and streets to collect and clean rainwater naturally. For example, Karens Minde Park now holds a lot of stormwater and has a special channel that guides and cleans rainwater. Meanwhile, Wuhan in China started its sponge city projects in 2015 with over €3 billion spent on wetlands, trees, and special pavements to soak up water and reduce flooding.

**Impact** – These efforts have helped both cities reduce flood damage, improve air quality, and support plants and animals. Wuhan saved around €150 million during floods by using sponge city features instead of only concrete pipes. The green spaces also cool the cities and make them healthier places to live. Using detailed satellite data from the Copernicus Land Monitoring Service helps planners understand where water soaks in well and where more improvements are needed.

**What's next step** – Cities will keep using satellite data to track how well their sponge city projects work and find new places to add green spaces or tree cover. This data helps make better plans and shows if nature-based solutions are protecting cities as storms get stronger.

**One-sentence takeaway** – By combining natural designs with satellite data, cities like Copenhagen and Wuhan are creating smarter ways to manage rainwater, reduce floods, and improve life for their residents.
articles.personality_title_fr: Comment des villes comme Copenhague et Wuhan utilisent la nature et les données pour lutter contre les inondations
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – De nombreuses villes doivent faire face à des tempêtes plus fortes, des inondations et des étés plus chauds. Pour y faire face, certaines adoptent l'idée de la "ville-éponge". Cela signifie concevoir parcs, rues et cours d'eau pour absorber l'eau de pluie comme une éponge, ce qui aide à réduire les inondations et rend les villes plus agréables à vivre.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Après une inondation majeure en 2011, Copenhague a investi plus d'un milliard d'euros pour se préparer aux futures tempêtes. La ville a construit de grands tunnels souterrains pour contenir l'eau d'inondation et transformé parcs et rues pour collecter et purifier naturellement l'eau de pluie. Par exemple, le parc Karens Minde peut maintenant retenir beaucoup d'eau de pluie et possède un canal spécial qui guide et filtre cette eau. Pendant ce temps, Wuhan en Chine a lancé ses projets de ville-éponge en 2015 avec plus de 3 milliards d'euros dépensés pour restaurer des zones humides, planter des arbres et poser des pavés spéciaux pour absorber l'eau et réduire les inondations.

**Impact** – Ces efforts ont aidé les deux villes à réduire les dégâts causés par les inondations, améliorer la qualité de l'air et soutenir la biodiversité. Wuhan a économisé environ 150 millions d'euros lors des inondations grâce aux infrastructures de ville-éponge plutôt qu'uniquement aux canalisations en béton. Les espaces verts rafraîchissent aussi les villes et rendent la vie plus saine. Les données satellites détaillées du Service de Surveillance de la Terre Copernicus aident les urbanistes à comprendre où l'eau est bien absorbée et où des améliorations sont nécessaires.

**Prochaine étape** – Les villes continueront d'utiliser les données satellites pour suivre l'efficacité de leurs projets de ville-éponge et trouver de nouveaux endroits pour ajouter des espaces verts ou des arbres. Ces données aident à mieux planifier et à vérifier si les solutions basées sur la nature protègent les villes face à des tempêtes plus fortes.

**Message clé en une phrase** – En combinant conception naturelle et données satellites, des villes comme Copenhague et Wuhan créent des moyens plus intelligents de gérer l'eau de pluie, réduire les inondations et améliorer la vie de leurs habitants.
articles.personality_title_es: Cómo ciudades como Copenhague y Wuhan usan la naturaleza y datos para combatir las inundaciones
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Muchas ciudades enfrentan tormentas más fuertes, inundaciones y veranos más calurosos. Para manejar esto, algunas están adoptando la idea de "ciudades esponja". Esto significa diseñar parques, calles y vías fluviales para absorber el agua de lluvia como una esponja, lo que ayuda a reducir inundaciones y hace que las ciudades sean mejores para vivir.

**Qué pasó** – Después de una gran inundación en 2011, Copenhague invirtió más de mil millones de euros para prepararse para futuras tormentas. La ciudad construyó grandes túneles subterráneos para almacenar agua de inundación y transformó parques y calles para recoger y limpiar el agua de lluvia de forma natural. Por ejemplo, el parque Karens Minde ahora puede retener mucha agua de lluvia y tiene un canal especial que guía y filtra el agua. Mientras tanto, Wuhan en China inició sus proyectos de ciudad esponja en 2015, con más de 3 mil millones de euros en humedales, árboles y pavimentos especiales para absorber agua y reducir inundaciones.

**Impacto** – Estos esfuerzos han ayudado a ambas ciudades a reducir daños por inundaciones, mejorar la calidad del aire y apoyar la biodiversidad. Wuhan ahorró cerca de 150 millones de euros durante inundaciones gracias a las características de la ciudad esponja en lugar de solo tuberías de concreto. Los espacios verdes también enfrían las ciudades y las hacen más saludables. Los datos detallados de satélites del Servicio de Monitoreo Terrestre Copernicus ayudan a los planificadores a saber dónde el agua se absorbe bien y dónde se necesitan mejoras.

**Próximo paso** – Las ciudades seguirán usando datos satelitales para monitorear qué tan bien funcionan sus proyectos de ciudad esponja y para encontrar nuevos lugares donde agregar espacios verdes o cobertura de árboles. Estos datos ayudan a planear mejor y a comprobar si las soluciones basadas en la naturaleza están protegiendo a las ciudades ante tormentas más fuertes.

**Frase clave** – Combinando diseños naturales con datos satelitales, ciudades como Copenhague y Wuhan están creando formas más inteligentes de manejar el agua de lluvia, reducir inundaciones y mejorar la vida de sus habitantes.

articles.title: This is where tree planting has the biggest climate impact
articles.summary: Planting more trees can help cool the planet and reduce fire risk—but where they are planted matters. According to UC Riverside researchers, tropical regions provide the most powerful climate benefits because trees there grow year-round, absorb more carbon dioxide, and cool the air through processes like evapotranspiration, or “tree sweating.”
articles.content:
More trees will cool the climate and suppress fires, but mainly if planted in the tropics, according to a new UC Riverside study.

The study, published in npj Climate and Atmospheric Science, found that tree planting is generally a net positive for the climate because it helps pull warming carbon out of the atmosphere. However, local effects on temperature not related to carbon varied significantly by region. At higher latitudes, trees could have a slight heating effect, while the opposite is true in the tropics.

"Our study found more cooling from planting in warm, wet regions, where trees grow year-round. Tropical trees not only pull carbon dioxide from the air, they also cool while releasing water vapor," said study first author and UCR graduate student James Gomez. "It's not that planting elsewhere doesn't help - it does - but the tropics offer the strongest returns per tree."

These findings mirror the results of an earlier UCR study that shows planting trees could cool the surface of the planet even more than previously expected. While that study factored in the chemical effects of trees interacting with the atmosphere, this study places more emphasis on understanding the physical effects of tree planting.

These effects include "tree sweating," or evapotranspiration. Tree roots pull water from the soil, which then travels up through the trunk and into the leaves. When pores in the leaves open up so the tree can take in carbon dioxide for photosynthesis, some of the water in the leaves evaporates into the air. This process cools the air on Earth's surface and cools the tree, too.

"It's just like the way sweating cools your body," Gomez said. "In the tropics, there is constantly water available for trees, and that increases transpiration."

Trees can also reduce the amount of sunlight that reaches the planet's surface. As they give off water vapor, the air can become more humid. More humidity can mean more clouds, and water vapor itself can soak up some sun. Both of these effects reduce the amount of sun that reaches the ground, giving a cooling effect.

The physical effects of the added trees yield weak global mean cooling of 0.01° F, although this cooling does become significant in the tropics at about 0.1° F, with some tropical regions like central Africa experiencing cooling up to 0.8° F.

Accounting for the carbon sequestration of the added trees, which here are approximated offline, is expected to amplify these cooling effects by about 0.15° F globally. The researchers note that better estimates of the carbon sequestration effects will be explored in a future study, where both the physical and carbon cycle effects of establishing new forests are interactively simulated.

"Though the non-CO2 effects are small, it is good news that they are not warming, which prior studies have indicated is likely," Gomez said.

For this study, the researchers also used a relatively realistic scenario, planting trees in places where they have been removed, avoiding deforestation, and limiting new trees to places where they would not displace peopleor too much agricultural land. In addition, the experiment used data from 12 climate models commonly used for international policy analysis, so the results would be more reliable than relying on a single model.

The researchers also found that, in some cases, trees can have a fire suppression effect. "In tropical savannahs, and in other places around the world, trees are much more fire resistant than grasses," Gomez said.

However, the study found that in parts of Canada and the northeastern U.S. trees would likely cause more fires and reduce cooling by absorbing too much sun.

"This is not an invitation to get rid of the trees growing there! They provide multiple benefits for ecosystems and diversity, reducing CO2 and cooling the surrounding areas," Gomez said.

"What we need is a Goldilocks zone of trees in each region. Just the right amount to have the strongest and most positive climate effects."
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a significant scientific study demonstrating that tree planting, especially in tropical regions, can have a strong cooling effect on the planet and reduce fire risks. This has broad implications for climate action and environmental policy worldwide. The study provides detailed insights into the mechanisms of cooling via evapotranspiration and carbon sequestration, offering actionable knowledge for maximizing the climate benefits of reforestation efforts. The findings are based on robust climate models and realistic scenarios, making the impact meaningful and well-substantiated.
articles.personality_title: Planting trees in the tropics cools the planet the most
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists know that planting trees helps fight climate change by absorbing carbon dioxide, a gas that warms the Earth. But trees can also affect local temperatures in other ways. Researchers wanted to find out where planting trees makes the biggest difference in cooling the planet.

**What happened** – A study by the University of California, Riverside, found that planting trees in tropical regions has the strongest cooling effect. This is because tropical trees grow all year, pull more carbon dioxide from the air, and cool the surface by releasing water vapor—a process like sweating called evapotranspiration. The study used data from 12 climate models and focused on realistic tree planting areas where forests were lost but avoided places that would harm people or important farmland.

**Impact** – The cooling effect of tropical trees is about ten times stronger than in colder regions. For example, parts of central Africa could cool by up to 0.8 degrees Fahrenheit due to new tree growth. Besides cooling, trees in tropical savannahs help reduce fires because they catch fire less easily than grasses. The study also showed that planting trees in some northern areas, like parts of Canada and the northeastern U.S., might increase fire risk and warming, so planting needs to be balanced carefully.

**What's next step** – Researchers plan to improve their understanding of how trees store carbon and affect climate by running more detailed computer simulations. This will help guide future tree planting efforts to focus on the best places and amounts of trees to plant for the most climate benefit without causing harm.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Planting trees in tropical regions offers the greatest cooling and fire-reducing benefits, making it a key strategy for fighting climate change effectively.
articles.personality_title_fr: Planter des arbres dans les tropiques refroidit le plus la planète
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques savent que planter des arbres aide à lutter contre le changement climatique en absorbant le dioxyde de carbone, un gaz qui réchauffe la Terre. Mais les arbres peuvent aussi influencer la température locale de différentes façons. Les chercheurs ont voulu découvrir où planter des arbres fait le plus grand effet de refroidissement.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une étude de l’Université de Californie à Riverside a montré que planter des arbres dans les régions tropicales a l’effet de refroidissement le plus fort. Les arbres tropicaux poussent toute l’année, absorbent plus de dioxyde de carbone et refroidissent la surface en libérant de la vapeur d’eau, un processus semblable à la transpiration appelé évapotranspiration. L’étude a utilisé des données de 12 modèles climatiques et s’est concentrée sur des zones réalistes où des forêts ont été perdues, tout en évitant les endroits qui pourraient nuire aux populations ou aux terres agricoles importantes.

**Impact** – L’effet de refroidissement des arbres tropicaux est environ dix fois plus fort que dans les régions plus froides. Par exemple, certaines parties de l’Afrique centrale pourraient se refroidir jusqu’à 0,8 degré Fahrenheit grâce à la croissance de nouveaux arbres. En plus du refroidissement, les arbres dans les savanes tropicales aident à réduire les incendies car ils brûlent moins facilement que les herbes. L’étude a aussi montré que planter des arbres dans certaines zones du nord, comme au Canada et dans le nord-est des États-Unis, pourrait augmenter le risque d’incendies et le réchauffement, donc il faut planter avec précaution.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs prévoient d’améliorer leur compréhension de la façon dont les arbres stockent le carbone et influencent le climat en réalisant des simulations informatiques plus détaillées. Cela aidera à mieux orienter les efforts de reforestation vers les meilleurs endroits et quantités d’arbres à planter pour un bénéfice climatique maximal sans causer de dégâts.

**En une phrase** – Planter des arbres dans les régions tropicales offre les plus grands bénéfices en refroidissement et réduction des incendies, en faisant une stratégie clé pour lutter efficacement contre le changement climatique.
articles.personality_title_es: Plantar árboles en los trópicos enfría más el planeta
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos saben que plantar árboles ayuda a combatir el cambio climático porque absorben dióxido de carbono, un gas que calienta la Tierra. Pero los árboles también pueden afectar la temperatura local de otras formas. Los investigadores querían saber dónde plantar árboles tiene el mayor efecto de enfriamiento.

**Qué pasó** – Un estudio de la Universidad de California en Riverside encontró que plantar árboles en las regiones tropicales tiene el efecto de enfriamiento más fuerte. Los árboles tropicales crecen todo el año, absorben más dióxido de carbono y enfrían la superficie al liberar vapor de agua, un proceso parecido a sudar llamado evapotranspiración. El estudio usó datos de 12 modelos climáticos y se centró en áreas realistas donde se perdieron bosques, evitando lugares que podrían afectar a personas o tierras agrícolas importantes.

**Impacto** – El efecto de enfriamiento de los árboles tropicales es unas diez veces más fuerte que en las regiones frías. Por ejemplo, algunas partes de África central podrían enfriarse hasta 0.8 grados Fahrenheit gracias al crecimiento de nuevos árboles. Además de enfriar, los árboles en sabanas tropicales ayudan a reducir incendios porque se queman menos fácilmente que los pastos. El estudio también mostró que plantar árboles en algunas zonas del norte, como partes de Canadá y el noreste de EE.UU., podría aumentar el riesgo de incendios y el calentamiento, por lo que se debe plantar con cuidado.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores planean mejorar su comprensión sobre cómo los árboles almacenan carbono y afectan el clima realizando simulaciones por computadora más detalladas. Esto ayudará a guiar futuros esfuerzos de plantación hacia los mejores lugares y cantidades de árboles para obtener el mayor beneficio climático sin causar daño.

**Una frase clave** – Plantar árboles en regiones tropicales ofrece los mayores beneficios de enfriamiento y reducción de incendios, siendo una estrategia clave para combatir el cambio climático de forma efectiva.

articles.title: Protect wildlife: Buy a print
articles.summary: They say a picture is worth a thousand words. These pictures might be worth even more. An initiative featuring the work of some of the world’s best nature photographers raises money for environmental conservation.
articles.content:
They say a picture is worth a thousand words. These pictures might be worth even more.

“Prints for Wildlife,” an initiative featuring the work of some of the world’s best nature photographers, has raised more than US$ 2 million for environmental conservation since 2020.

This year’s edition — dubbed “Edition Hope” — runs for one month starting today, featuring limited-edition prints donated by more than 200 renowned wildlife and nature photographers, including Joel Sartore, Georgina Goodwin, Suzi Eszterhas and more.

The initiative is well-timed, with conservation programs around the world facing abrupt funding cuts and a possible future where nature is undervalued.

“The striking images that are part of this collection so perfectly illustrate the power and beauty of nature in its many forms,” said Daniela Raik, interim CEO of Conservation International. “There is no question that everything is connected and when nature thrives, so do we. Thanks to the commitment from many celebrated photographers, this art will give people the opportunity to connect with the natural world each day in their own space, while at the same time supporting its resilience and longevity for the benefit of us all.”

Prints will be available for one month only at printsforwildlife.org, starting today and closing Sept. 21.

Each print is priced at US$ 125 — all net proceeds (after printing and handling) will directly benefit Conservation International.

Bruno Vander Velde is the managing director of storytelling at Conservation International. Want to read more stories like this? Sign up for email updates. Also, please consider supporting our critical work.
articles.reasoning: The article describes a successful fundraising initiative leveraging wildlife photography to raise over $2 million for environmental conservation, supporting global efforts to protect nature amid funding challenges. It highlights a meaningful, large-scale positive impact on conservation, involving well-known photographers and a clear, focused campaign.
articles.personality_title: Wildlife photos raise over $2 million for nature conservation
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Conservation groups around the world often struggle to get enough money to protect animals and nature. This can make it hard to keep important programs going.

**What happened** – Since 2020, an initiative called “Prints for Wildlife” has sold special wildlife photos to raise money for conservation. These photos come from more than 200 famous nature photographers. The latest event, called “Edition Hope,” started recently and will last one month. Each photo costs $125, and all the money earned goes to Conservation International, a group that helps protect nature.

**Impact** – This initiative has raised more than $2 million so far. It helps people connect with nature by bringing beautiful animal pictures into their homes. At the same time, it provides important funds to protect wildlife and their habitats, especially when other funding is shrinking.

**What's next step** – The current sale will end on September 21. After that, organizers hope to continue this project each year to keep raising money and awareness for conservation. People who enjoy nature can visit printsforwildlife.org to buy prints and support the cause.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Selling wildlife photos has become a powerful way to raise millions of dollars and support nature conservation worldwide.

articles.title: US mines are literally throwing away critical minerals
articles.content:
The United States is home to dozens of active mines. Some extract copper, while others dig for iron. Whatever the resource, however, it usually makes up a small fraction of the rock pulled from the ground. The rest is typically ignored. Wasted.

“We’re only producing a few commodities,” said Elizabeth Holley, a professor of mining engineering at the Colorado School of Mines. “The question is: What else is in those rocks?”

The answer: a lot.

In a study published today by the journal Science, Holley and her colleagues aimed to quantify what else is in those rocks. They found that, across 70 critical elements at 54 active mines, the potential for recovery is enormous. There is enough lithium in one year of U.S. mine waste, for example, to power 10 million electric vehicles. For manganese, it’s enough for 99 million. Those figures far surpass both U.S. import levels of those elements and current demand for them.

To support our nonprofit environmental journalism, please consider disabling your ad-blocker to allow ads on Grist. Here's How

Critical minerals are essential to the production of lithium-ion batteries, solar panels, and other low- or zero-carbon technologies powering the clean energy transition. Where the U.S. gets those minerals has long been a politically fraught topic.

The vast majority of lithium comes from Australia, Chile, and China, for example, while cobalt predominantly comes from the Democratic Republic of the Congo. While securing a domestic supply of rare or critical materials has been a U.S. policy goal for decades, the push has intensified in recent years. Former president Joe Biden’s landmark climate legislation, the 2022 Inflation Reduction Act, included incentives for domestic critical mineral production, and this year, President Donald Trump signed an executive order invoking wartime powers that would allow more leasing and extraction on federal lands.

“Our national and economic security are now acutely threatened by our reliance upon hostile foreign powers’ mineral production,” the order read. “It is imperative for our national security that the United States take immediate action to facilitate domestic mineral production to the maximum possible extent.”

Trump also made critical minerals a cornerstone of continued support to Ukraine. Meanwhile, China recently expanded export controls on rare earth metals, underscoring the precarious nature of the global market.

To support our nonprofit environmental journalism, please consider disabling your ad-blocker to allow ads on Grist. Here's How

Holley’s research indicates that increased domestic byproduct recovery could address this instability. Even a 1 percent recovery rate, it found, would “substantially reduce” import reliance for most elements. Recovering 4 percent of lithium would completely offset current imports.

“We could focus on mines that are already corporate and simply add additional circuits to their process,” said Holley. “It would be a really quick way of bringing a needed mineral into production.”

This latest research is “very valuable,” said Hamidreza Samouei, a professor of petroleum engineering at Texas A&M University who wasn’t involved in the study. He sees it as a great starting point for a multipronged approach to tackling the byproduct problem and moving toward a zero-waste system. Other areas that will need attention, he said, include looking beyond discarded rock to the “huge” amounts of water that a mine uses. He also believes that the government should play a more aggressive policy and regulatory role in pushing for critical mineral recovery.

“Mining is a very old-fashioned industry,” said Samouei. “Who is going to take the risk?”

The Department of Energy recently announced a byproduct recovery pilot program, and the Pentagon took a $400 million stake in the operator of the country’s only rare-earth metal mine. At the same time, Congress recently repealed large chunks of the Inflation Reduction Act, which would have driven demand for critical minerals, and has slashed federal funding to the U.S. Geological Survey and the Department of Energy’s Office of Science, among other research arms.

The general thrust of the Science study is “not new,” said Isabel Barton, a professor of geological engineering at the University of Arizona. “It is a very hot topic in mining these days.”

The attention is contributing to a burgeoning shift in thinking, from an intense focus on the target mineral to consideration of what else could be produced, including critical minerals. “There are some that are probably relatively simple. There are others that are heinously difficult to get to,” said Barton, and whether a mineral is recovered will ultimately come down to cost. “Mining companies are there to make a profit.”

Figuring out the most economically viable way forward is exactly the next step Holley hopes this research will inform. Byproduct potential varies considerably by mine, and the analysis, she said, can help pinpoint where to potentially find which minerals. For instance, the Red Dog mine in Alaska appears to have the largest germanium potential in the country, while nickel could be found at the Stillwater and East Boulder mines in Montana.

“The [research and development] funding on critical minerals has been a little bit of a scattershot,” she said. “Our paper allows the development of a strategy.”
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a significant environmental and economic opportunity to recover critical minerals from existing U.S. mine waste, which could reduce reliance on foreign imports and support clean energy technologies. This has broad implications for national security, climate action, and sustainable resource use. The detailed study and policy context provide substantial substance and meaningful impact for society.
articles.personality_title: U.S. mines hold hidden minerals that could power millions of electric vehicles
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** –
The United States has many active mines that dig up metals like copper and iron. Usually, miners only keep the main metal they want and throw away the rest of the rock, which often contains other valuable minerals.

**What happened** –
A new study led by Elizabeth Holley from the Colorado School of Mines looked at 54 active U.S. mines and found that the waste rock contains large amounts of critical minerals like lithium and manganese. For example, the lithium in just one year’s worth of waste could power 10 million electric cars. This discovery shows there is a lot of untapped potential in U.S. mine waste.

**Impact** –
These minerals are very important for making batteries, solar panels, and other clean energy tools. Right now, the U.S. depends on other countries like Australia, Chile, and China for many of these minerals. Using waste from U.S. mines could reduce this dependence, improve national security, and help the country produce more clean energy technology at home.

**What's next step** –
Experts suggest adding new steps to current mining processes to recover these minerals from waste. The government is starting pilot programs to encourage this, but more research and funding are needed. The study helps identify which mines have the most potential for certain minerals, guiding future efforts.

**One-sentence takeaway** –
U.S. mine waste contains enough critical minerals to support millions of electric vehicles, offering a new way to boost clean energy and reduce reliance on foreign supplies.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les mines américaines cachent des minéraux essentiels pour des millions de voitures électriques
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** –
Les États-Unis possèdent de nombreuses mines actives qui extraient des métaux comme le cuivre et le fer. En général, les mineurs ne conservent que le métal principal recherché et jettent le reste de la roche, qui contient souvent d’autres minéraux précieux.

**Ce qui s’est passé** –
Une nouvelle étude dirigée par Elizabeth Holley de la Colorado School of Mines a examiné 54 mines actives aux États-Unis et découvert que les déchets miniers contiennent de grandes quantités de minéraux critiques comme le lithium et le manganèse. Par exemple, le lithium contenu dans les déchets d’une seule année pourrait alimenter 10 millions de voitures électriques. Cette découverte montre un potentiel important dans les déchets miniers américains.

**Impact** –
Ces minéraux sont essentiels pour fabriquer des batteries, des panneaux solaires et d’autres technologies propres. Actuellement, les États-Unis dépendent d’autres pays comme l’Australie, le Chili et la Chine pour beaucoup de ces minéraux. Utiliser les déchets des mines américaines pourrait réduire cette dépendance, renforcer la sécurité nationale et aider à produire plus de technologies propres localement.

**Prochaine étape** –
Les experts suggèrent d’ajouter de nouvelles étapes aux processus miniers actuels pour récupérer ces minéraux des déchets. Le gouvernement lance des programmes pilotes pour encourager cela, mais davantage de recherches et de financements sont nécessaires. L’étude aide à identifier quelles mines ont le plus de potentiel pour certains minéraux, guidant ainsi les efforts futurs.

**Résumé en une phrase** –
Les déchets miniers américains contiennent suffisamment de minéraux critiques pour soutenir des millions de voitures électriques, offrant une nouvelle façon de renforcer l’énergie propre et de réduire la dépendance aux importations.
articles.personality_title_es: Las minas de EE. UU. esconden minerales clave para millones de vehículos eléctricos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** –
Estados Unidos tiene muchas minas activas que extraen metales como cobre y hierro. Normalmente, los mineros solo conservan el metal principal que buscan y tiran el resto de la roca, que a menudo contiene otros minerales valiosos.

**Qué pasó** –
Un nuevo estudio dirigido por Elizabeth Holley de la Colorado School of Mines analizó 54 minas activas en EE. UU. y encontró que los residuos mineros contienen grandes cantidades de minerales críticos como litio y manganeso. Por ejemplo, el litio en los residuos de un año podría alimentar 10 millones de vehículos eléctricos. Esto muestra un gran potencial sin aprovechar en los residuos mineros del país.

**Impacto** –
Estos minerales son esenciales para fabricar baterías, paneles solares y otras tecnologías limpias. Actualmente, EE. UU. depende de otros países como Australia, Chile y China para muchos de estos minerales. Usar los residuos de las minas estadounidenses podría reducir esta dependencia, mejorar la seguridad nacional y ayudar a producir más tecnología limpia en casa.

**Próximo paso** –
Los expertos sugieren agregar pasos nuevos a los procesos mineros actuales para recuperar estos minerales de los residuos. El gobierno está comenzando programas piloto para fomentar esto, pero se necesita más investigación y financiamiento. El estudio ayuda a identificar qué minas tienen más potencial para ciertos minerales, guiando los esfuerzos futuros.

**Resumen en una frase** –
Los residuos de las minas en EE. UU. contienen suficientes minerales críticos para apoyar millones de vehículos eléctricos, ofreciendo una nueva forma de impulsar la energía limpia y reducir la dependencia de suministros extranjeros.
